handDesc.p: Halantas. Final N in line 21 is essentially identical to a na, raised above normal height.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is above the character to which it belongs, or above headline to the right of that character; occasionally atop the next character, e.g. l13 kuṭuṁbinaḥ within the i marker. Short and long i/ī are not clearly distinguishable, but i seems to be a closed circle while ī appears to be open on the left, with a little hook at the opening; e.g. sti and śrī side by side in line 1; śī in line 5 is good example of the long ī. Headmarks are large horizontal lines with small horns on each side.

app.note: The vowel of ḷ may be ū, or the engraver may have started engraving ḷya and then corrected.

There is little damage here; in fact the most damaged part of this locus is the last three characters, of whose reading I am quite certain. The preceding characters, however, are ambiguous on account of the script and the execution, and I am unable to offer a satisfactory reading. It is likely that multiple scribal errors are involved in addition to the ambiguous characters. The first problematic character, read as ṇa, might well be nā or ya, and reading vā or śā is not out of the question. The second definitely looks like ggi, but either of its consonant components could perhaps be dh instead of g. This is probably followed by a visarga, but it is just possible that this is instead a vowel marker (for e or part of o) attached to the next character. The third character looks much, but not entirely, like the first, so all possibilities listed for that also apply here, with the added complication that there may be a vowel marker prefixed to this character. This is definitely followed by rā, and the next two characters resemble one another but are not identical. The first could be bhi, śi or ni, less probably ti, vi or ci; the second is most likely śī but may perhaps be bhī or nī. In addition to the problems listed so far, any of the i-s read here as short may have been meant for long and vice versa. The closest to an intelligible phrase that I can obtain from the text is vāri-rāśi-śītīkr̥ta (assuming scribal omission of ri), but I have no inkling what ṇaggiḥ may be. I would expect this phrase to resemble the preceding and following qualifier, and thus to include a simile with iva and a double entendre. The double entendre may perhaps be that Vijayāditya's army (cakra) is “cooled” (i.e., its martial ardour is diminished) only when it reaches the ocean; in this, he may be compared to the moon (?), whose orbit (cakra) is cooled by water and by the signs of the zodiac - but this is probably just my forced attempt to make sense of a text that was probably meant to be something different. There is also a possibility that the end of this locus should be read śitīkr̥ta, in which case the two relevant meanings of śitīkr̥ta-cakra may be “sharpened discus” and “brightened domain;” the rest of the phrase should then somehow liken the king to Viṣṇu. Related grants offer no better clue; the only expressions involving cakra that I am aware of are cakradhara Ivāpratihata-cakraḥ in the Peṇukapaṟu grant of Jayasiṁha I and viṣṇor iva sva-cakra-nandakasya in the Koṟṟapaṟṟu grant of Vijayāditya II.

div.p: The ARIE report reads the name of the donated village as Maṁgaveḍu, and identifies it with modern Maṅginapūḍi in Bandar taluk of Kistna district. The reading seems doubtful to me, and I therefore prefer to name the charter after its findspot. The report identifies Krovaśiri with modern Krōsūru in Sattenapalle taluk of Guntur district. Several donees hailing from Krovaśiri are also mentioned in the Koṟṟapaṟṟu grant of Vijayāditya II (none of them are of the Bhāradvāja gotra).

The ARIE report further states that the ājñapti of the grant is Paṇḍaraṅga, “the bee at the lotus-feet of Guṇagāṅka-Vijayāditya.” Neither the name nor the description appear anywhere in the photos available online. The photos include one blank face, which is probably 1 recto, so it is possible that a description of the executor (perhaps an anuṣṭubh stanza) was written on 3 verso, of which no photo has been published.

Reported in 7A/1938-392 with discussion at 71-724. Although the report says an edition was to be published in Epigraphia Indica, this does not appear to have happened. I know of no published edition of these plates. The present edition has been prepared for DHARMA by Dániel Balogh on the basis of photos published by the Indian Museum (Kolkata).http://museumsofindia.gov.in/repository/record/im_kol-11358-19. The photos show the seal, four inscribed faces and one blank face. The sixth face may not be blank; see the commentary.
